content.description:
“[Working in the coal mines] women’s nature becomes impregnated with a coarseness altogether too masculine. [She acquires] the most detestable education, the grossest language, the basest manners. Woman goes there to cast off the principal qualities that distinguish her sex; there she contracts men’s habits, the allures of independence and liberty which later become the cause of disputes, of quarrels, and even of acts of violence. Earning a rather high wage, she becomes extravagant, and no longer knows the value of money. Habituated to going out every day, her house’s interior becomes a burden.”
Dr. Jean-François Vleminckx, report to the Belgian Royal Academy of Medicine, 1870
content.question: Vleminckx’ perspective in the report best demonstrates which of the following social developments of the nineteenth century?

choices.label: The growth of class consciousness within the proletariat and bourgeoisie
The development of philanthropic organizations by the middle class
The growth of the cult of domesticity and the increased focus among the bourgeoisie on the nuclear family
The acceptance of the bourgeois ideal of companionate marriage by the working class

content.answer: The growth of the cult of domesticity and the increased focus among the bourgeoisie on the nuclear family

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Explain how a specific historical development or process is situated within a broader historical context.
